title: The Cubical Homology of Trace Monoids

title_detail.value: The Cubical Homology of Trace Monoids

summary:
This article contains an overview of the results of the author in a field of
algebraic topology used in computer science. The relationship between the
cubical homology groups of generalized tori and homology groups of partial
trace monoid actions is described. Algorithms for computing the homology groups
of asynchronous systems, Petri nets, and Mazurkiewicz trace languages are
shown.

author: Ahmet A. Husainov
arxiv_comment:
21 pages, International Conference "Toric Topology and Automorphic
  Functions'' September 05-10, 2011 Khabarovsk
fulltext:
THE CUBICAL HOMOLOGY OF TRACE MONOIDS

arXiv:1110.6293v1 [math.AT] 28 Oct 2011

A. A. Husainov, husainov51@yandex.ru
Abstract
This article contains an overview of the results of the author in a
field of algebraic topology used in computer science. The relationship
between the cubical homology groups of generalized tori and homology
groups of partial trace monoid actions is described. Algorithms for
computing the homology groups of asynchronous systems, Petri nets,
and Mazurkiewicz trace languages are shown.

Keywords: semicubical set, homology of small categories, free partially
commutative monoid, trace monoid, asynchronous transition system, Petri
nets, trace languages.
2000 Mathematics Subject Classification 18G10, 18G35, 55U10, 68Q10,
68Q85

Introduction
Trace monoids have found many applications in computer science [17], [3].
M. Bednarczyk [2] studied and applied the category of asynchronous systems.
The author has proved that any asynchronous system can be regarded as a
partial trace monoid with action on a set. It is allowed to build homology
theory for the category of asynchronous systems and Petri nets [9]. In this
paper we also introduce a homology for Mazurkiewicz trace languages. It
should be noted that the homology theory was introduced and studied for
higher dimensional automata in the works [7] and [6]. E. Haucourt [8] applied
the Baues-Wirsching homology.
We study of a relationship between the cubical homology of generalized
tori and homology of a trace monoid action on a set. We build the algorithms
for the computing the homology groups of asynchronous systems, elementary Petri nets, and Mazurkiewicz trace languages. It allows us to solve the
problem posed in [9, Open problem 1] of the constructing an algorithm for
computing homology groups of the elementary Petri nets.

1

 1

Trace monoids and their partial actions

This section is devoted to the basic definitions and the problems that have
appeared.

1.1

Notations

We first describe our notations. Let Set be a category of sets and maps and
let Ab be a category of Abelian groups and homomorphisms. Denote by Z
the set of the additive group of integers. Let N be the set of nonnegative
integers or the free monoid {1, a, a2, * * * } generated by one element. Given a
category A denote by Aop the opposite category. Denote by Ob A the class
of all objects and Mor A the class of all morphisms in the category A. Given
objects a, b ∈ Ob A denote by A(a, b) the set of all morphisms a → b. For
any small category C , functors F : C → A will be called diagrams of objects
in A on C . In this case, along with the notation F : C → A we use the
notation {F (c)}c∈C . The category AC of functors C → A is called to be a
diagram category.
Let ∆ Z : C → Ab be the diagram having the value Z at each c ∈ ObC
and the value 1 Z at each α ∈ MorC .
L Given a family of Abelian groups {Aj }j∈J the direct sum is denoted by
Aj . Elements of summands are denoted as pairs (j, g) with j ∈ J and
j∈J
L
g ∈ Aj . If Aj = A for all j ∈ J, then this direct is denoted
A. If instead
j∈J

of a set J indicated a cardinal number p = |J|, then the direct coproduct is
denoted by A(p) .

1.2

Trace monoids

Let E be a set and let I ⊆ E × E be an arbitrary subset. The set I ⊆ E × E
is an independence relation on E if the following conditions are satisfied:
• (∀a ∈ E)(a, a) ∈
/I ,
• (∀a ∈ E)(∀b ∈ E) (a, b) ∈ I ⇒ (b, a) ∈ I.
Let E ∗ be the free monoid generated by a set E. It consists of the words
in alphabet E. The binary operation is defined as the concatenation of words
(a1 * * * am , b1 * * * bn ) 7→ a1 * * * am b1 * * * bn . The empty word is denoted by 1.
2

 Definition 1.1 Let I be an independence relation on a set E. A trace
monoid (or free partially commutative monoid) M(E, I) is the factor monoid
E ∗ /(≡) by a least equivalence relation for which uabv ≡ ubav, for all (a, b) ∈
I, u ∈ E ∗ , v ∈ E ∗ . Elements a, b ∈ E for which (a, b) ∈ I are called
commuting generators.
This definition is more general than given in [3] since we do not demand that
E is finite.
For example, if E = {a, b}, I = {(a, b), (b, a)}, then M(E, I) ∼
= N2 is the
free commutative monoid generated by two elements.
If I = ∅, then M(E, I) = E ∗ .
Any element w = a1 * * * an ∈ M(E, I) of a trace monoid can be interpreted
as finite sequence of instructions a1 , a2 , * * * , an in a program. The relation I
consists of pairs (a, b) instructions which can be executed concurrenrly.

1.3

State space

A partial map f : E ⇀ E ′ between sets E and E ′ is a relation f ⊆ E × E ′
for which (e, e′1 ) ∈ f & (e, e′2 ) ∈ f implies e′1 = e′2 . Let P Set be the category
of sets and partial maps between them. Any trace monoid M(E, I) can be
considered as a category with the unique object denoted by o(M(E, I)).
A partial trace monoid action of M(E, I) on a set S is a functor S :
M(E, I)op → P Set such that its value at o(M(E, I)) equals S. We denote
S(w)(s) by s * w. A state space (M(E, I), S) consists of a trace monoid
M(E, I) with a partial action on a set S. A state space (M(E, I), S) is
determined by partial maps (−) * a : S ⇀ S corresponding to a ∈ E. Hence,
it can be given by a directed graph with vertexes s ∈ S and labeled edges
a
s → s * e.
For example, if E = {a, b} and I = {(a, b), (b, a)}, then the directed graph
with labeled edges

1.4

Augmented state space

In order to make the action (M(E, I), S) to be total, we add the state ∗
and extend the partial maps (−) * a : S ⇀ S to the (total) maps (−) * a :
S ⊔ {∗} → S ⊔ {∗} acting by s * a = ∗ if s * a is not defined. Let S∗ = S ⊔ {∗}
and ∗ * a = ∗. The the pair (M(E, I), S∗ ) consists of a trace monoid with
the total action on the set S∗ . This pair is called the state space with an
augmentation.
For example, the previous state space gives the augmented state space

Let (M(E, I), S) be a state space. Consider an augmented state category
K∗ (S) as follows. Its class of objects is the set S∗ = S ⊔ {∗}. Morphisms
s → s′ are triples (s, w, s′) of s ∈ S∗ , s′ ∈ S∗ , w ∈ M(E, I).
For any subset Σ ⊆ S∗ , let K(Σ) ⊆ K∗ (S) denotes a full subcategory
with class of objects Σ. For Σ = S, K(S) ⊆ K∗ (S) will be called a state
category.

1.5

of Abelian groups and homomorphisms.

1.6

Homology of state categories, asynchronous systems and Petri nets

For an arbitrary small category C , let ∆ Z : C → Ab be the functor taking
constant values Z at objects and 1 Z : Z → Z at morphisms of C .
By [9], an asynchronous system can be defined as a triple (S, s0 , M(E, I))
where (S, M(E, I)) is a state space and s0 ∈ S is a distinguished element.
Elements of S(s0 ) = {s * μ|μ ∈ M(E, I)} ⊆ S are reachable states. Homology
groups of asynchronous system with coefficients in an arbitrary functor F :
K(S(s0 ))
K(S) → Ab are Abelian groups −

F |K(S(s0 )) .
→n
B
For a set B, denote by 2 the set of all its subsets.
A CE net [9] or Petri net [21] is a quintuple (B, E, pre, post, s0) consisting
of finite sets B and E, the maps pre, post : E → 2B , and a subset s0 ⊆ B.
Let N = (B, E, pre, post, s0 ) be a CE net. Define an relation I ⊆ E × E
as the set of pairs (a, b) for which (pre(a) ∪ post(a)) ∩ (pre(b) ∪ post(b)) = ∅.
5

 To every element e ∈ E we assign a partial mapping (−)*e : 2B ⇀ 2B defined
for s ⊆ B satisfying to the condition
(pre(e) ⊆ s) & (post(e) ∩ s = ∅).
In these cases, we take s * e = (s \ pre(e)) ∪ post(e) [17]. This define a
partial action of M(E, I) on the set 2B . Assuming S = 2B , we get an
asynchronous system (S, s0 , M(E, I)), which corresponds to the CE net N =
K(S(s0 ))
(B, E, pre, post, s0). The homology groups Hn (N ) defined as −

where S(s0 ) is the set of reachable states.
In [9], it was built an algorithm for computing the group H1 (K(S), ∆ Z)
and hence H1 (N ). It was formulated the following
Problem 1 Construct an algorithm for computing integral homology of CE
nets.
By the definition of Hn (N ), this problem will be solved wenn we find
an algorithm to compute the homology groups Hn (K(S), ∆ Z) for the state
categories.
In [9], it was proved that if M(E, I) does not contain triples of pairwise independent generators, then Hn (K∗ (S), ∆ Z) = 0 for n > 2. It was
formulated
Problem 2 Let n > 0 be the maximal number of pairwise independent generators. Prove that Hk (K∗ (S), F ) = 0 for any k > n and for any functor
F : K∗ (S) → Ab.
In the case of finite E, this conjecture proved by L. Yu. Polyakova [20].
In general solved by the author [10].
Problem 2 could not be solved for a long time. We present a way to solve
this problem. Detailed proofs will be published shortly.

2

Semicubical sets and generalized tori

Recall the definition of semicubical set and its geometric realization. Get
acquainted with generalized tori and assign to any partial trace monoid action
a semicubical set.

6

 2.1

Semicubical sets

Let ✷+ be the category of posets In , n ∈ N, where I is the set {0, 1} ordered
by 0 < 1. Morphisms in ✷+ are increasing maps admitting a decomposition
in the composition of maps δik,ε : Ik−1 → Ik , 1 6 i 6 k, ε ∈ I defined as
δik,ε (x1 , * * * , xk−1) = (x1 , * * * , xi−1 , ε, xi , * * * , xk−1 ).
A semicubical set is any functor X : ✷op
+ →Set. In [7], it is called precubical
set. Morphisms between semicubical sets are defined as natural transformations. Any semicubical set can be given by a pair (Xn , ∂in,ε ) consisting of
sequence of sets (Xn )n∈ N and a family of maps ∂in,ε : Xn → Xn−1 , defined
for 1 6 i 6 n, ε ∈ {0, 1}, and satisfying to the condition
n−1,β
∂in−1,α ◦ ∂jn,β = ∂j−1
◦ ∂in,α , for α, β ∈ {0, 1}, n > 2 and 1 6 i < j 6 n.

These maps will be equal ∂ik,ε = X(δik,ε).
Semicubical objects in an arbitrary category A are defined similarly as
functors ✷op
+ → A.

2.2

Geometric realization
op

Let X ∈ Set✷+ be a semicubical set. Its the geometric realization [4] is
defined as the topological quotient space
a
|X|✷+ =
Xn × [0, 1]n / ≡
n∈ N

with respect the smallest equivalence relation satisfying
(∂in,ν x, t1 , * * * , tn−1 ) ≡ (x, t1 , * * * , ti−1 , ν, ti , * * * , tn−1 ),
for all n > 0, ∈ {0, 1}, 1 6 i 6 n, ti ∈ [0, 1]. Geometric realization determine
the functor |−|✷+ assigning to every morphism of semicubical sets f : X → Y
the continuous map |f |✷+ : |X|✷+ → |Y |✷+ such that |f |✷+ (x, t1 , * * * , tn ) =
(f (x), t1 , * * * , tn ). The functor | − |✷+ can be constructed from the functor
H : ✷+ → Top, H( In ) = [0, 1]n , as in [5, Prop. II.1.3] by extending to the
category of semicubical sets. It follows from [5, Prop. II.1.3] that | − |✷+
preserves colimits.

7

 2.3

Generalized tori

For a trace monoid M(E, I) with a total order relation < on E, the generalized torus T (E, I) is the semicubical set (Tn (E, I), ∂in,ε ) such that
Tn (E, I) = {(a1 , * * * , an ) ∈ E n : ai < aj & (ai , aj ) ∈ I for all 1 6 i < j 6 n}
and ∂in,ε (a1 , * * * , an ) = (a1 , * * * , ai−1 , ai+1 , * * * , an ), for all n > 0, 1 6 i 6 n,
ε ∈ {0, 1}.
For example, if E = {a1 , * * * , an } ordered by a1 < a2 < * * * an with I
consisting of all pairs (ai , aj ) for which i 6= j, then the geometric realization
|T (E, I)|✷+ is homeomorphic to the usual n-dimensional torus.

the semicubical set Q(E, I, S) with
Qn (E, I, S) = {(x, a1 , * * * , an ) ∈ S∗ × Tn (E, I)|
ai < aj & (ai , ai ) for all 1 6 i < j 6 n}.
with the boundary maps ∂in,ε (x, a1 , * * * , an ) = (x*aεi , a1 , * * * , ai−1 , ai+1 , * * * , an )
for 1 6 i 6 n, n > 1, ε ∈ {0, 1}. Here a0 = 1 and a1 = a.

3

Homology of factorization category

In this section, we study and apply the Leech homology and cohomology
groups of trace monoids.

3.1

Factorization category

Let C be a small category. Given α ∈ Mor C , denote by cod α its codomain
and dom α the domain.
The factorization category F act(C ) has objects Ob (F act(C )) = Mor C ,
and for every α, β ∈ Mor (C ) each element of F act(C )(α, β) is determined
by a pair (f, g) of f, g ∈ Mor (C ) making commutative the diagram
codO α

For example, any monoid M considered as a small category with unique
object has the factorization category F act(M) such that Ob (F act(M)) = M.
(f,g)

Morphisms are given by quadruples α → β of f, α, β, g ∈ M satisfying
gαf = β.
10

 3.2

Leech homology of generalized tori

In this subsection, we present the results published in the articles [12] and
[11].
Leech homology groups of a monoid M with coefficients in a functor F :
F act(M)op → Ab are defined as the groups Hn (F act(M)op , F ), n > 0.
Given trace monoid M(E, I), let S : ✷+ /T (E, I) → F act(M(E, I))
be the functor assigning to each (a1 , * * * , an ) ∈ Ob ✷+ /T (E, I) the object
a1 * * * an ∈ M(E, I) = Ob F act(M(E, I)). Each morphism of the category
✷+ /T (E, I) can be decomposed into a composition of morphisms of the form
(δin,ε ), (a1 , * * * , ai−1 , ai+1 , * * * , an ), (a1 , * * * , an ). Therefore, it suffices to define
S on the morphisms of this kind. Let
S(δin,ε , (a1 , * * * , ai−1 , ai+1 , * * * , an ), (a1 , * * * , an )) =

where a0 = 1, and a1 = a.

3.3

Global dimension of a trace monoid

11

 Given semicubical set X and a functor G : ✷+ /X → Ab, define cohomology groups H n (X, G) of X with coefficients in G similarly to homology
groups of semicubical set. Easy to see that H n (X, G) ∼
= H n (✷+ /X, G).
The proof of [12, Theorem 2.2] contains the assertion that for each α ∈
Ob F act(M(E, I)), Hn (S/α, ∆ Z) = 0 for n > 0, and H0 (S/α, ∆ Z) = Z.
Hence, it follows from the Oberst Theorem [11, Prop. 1] the following assertion.
Theorem 3.2 For any functors F : F act(M(E, I)) → Ab and for all n > 0,
there are isomorphisms H n (F act(M(E, I)), F ) ∼
= H n (T (E, I), F ◦ S).
Given Abelian category A its global dimension gl.dim A is a supremum
of n > 0 for which the functors Ext n (−, =) are not equal to 0. Theorem 3.2
leads us to the following generalization of Hilbert's Syzygy Theorem.
Theorem 3.3 Let A be an Abelian category with coproducts and let M(E, I)
be a trace monoid. If a maximal cardinality of pairwise independent elements
of E equals n < ∞, then
gl.dim AM (E,I) = n + gl.dim A
in each of the following cases:
(i) A has exact coproducts (i.e. A satisfies to the axiom AB4),
(ii) A has enough projectives.
Conjecture 1 This is true for all Abelian categories with coproducts.
Example 3.1 Let k be a field and E = {x1 , x2 , x3 , x4 , x5 } be the set of variables. Suppose that the independence relation I ⊂ E × E is given by the
following graph with vertexes E and edges I:

3.4

Homology of augmented state category

Consider the functor cod : F act(C ) → C , α 7→ cod (α), (α −→ β) 7→. For

3.5

Homology of Mazurkiewicz trace languages

Given v, w ∈ M(E, I), we let v 6 w if there exists u ∈ M(E, I) such that
vu = w. This relation makes M(E, I) into a partially ordered set, which we
denote by P (E, I). A trace language is any set of traces.
Definition 3.3 A set L ⊆ M(E, I) is prefix closed if for all v ∈ M(E, I)
and w ∈ L the relation v < w implies v ∈ L.
Let L ⊆ M(E, I) be a prefix closed trace language. We have the pair
(M(E, I), L) consisting of the trace monoid with the following partial action
for v ∈ L, μ ∈ M(E, I).

vμ,
if vμ ∈ L
v*μ=
undef ined, otherwise.
For any functor F : K∗ (L) → Ab, we can consider the homology groups
Hn (K∗ (L), F ). The groups Hn (K∗ (L), ∆ Z) are called integral homology
groups.

3.6

Homology groups of the poset of traces

Given prefix closed language L ⊆ M(E, I), let Z[L] : P (E, I) → Ab be a
functor with values Z[L](v) = Z for v ∈ L and Z[L](v) = 0, otherwise.
For u 6 v ∈ L, we will define Z[L](u 6 v) = 1 Z . We study the homology
groups Hn (P (E, I), Z[L]) of the poset P (E, I) and their relationship with
Hn (K∗ (L), ∆ Z).
Denote by pn the cardinality of the set of n-cliques in the graph (E, I).
In particular, p0 = 1 as the number of empty subsets in E, p1 = |E|. For

Conjecture 2 For any trace monoid M(E, I) with partial action on a set
S, the Abelian group H1 (K∗ (S), ∆ Z) is free.
Note the following homological properties of partially ordered set of traces.
We assume that the language of traces L is prefix closed.
• If I = {(a, b) ∈ E × E|a 6= b} and hence M(E, I) is commutative, then
Hn (P (E, I), Z[L]) = 0 for all n > 1.
• If I = ∅ and hence M(E, I) is free, then Hn (P (E, I), Z[L]) = 0 for all
n > 2.
• For arbitrary finitely generated Abelian groups A1 , A2 , ..., An with free
A1 , there exists a trace monoid M(E, I) such that Hn (P (E, I), Z[{1}]) ∼
=
Ak for all 1 6 k 6 n.

3.7

Baues-Wirsching homology of the state category

Let M(E, I) be an arbitrary trace monoid an let X be a right M(E, I)-set.
Recall that K(X) denotes the category of states with objects x ∈ X and
μ
morphisms x → xμ for x ∈ X and μ ∈ M(E, I). Considering M(E, I) as a
category with an unique object we can define a functor U : K(X) → M(E, I)
μ
assigning to each morphism x → xμ the morphism μ ∈ M(E, I). Applying
the functor F act to U, we can consider a functor F act(U) : F act(K(X)) →
F act(M(E, I)). For any functor F : F act(K(X))op → Ab, there exists its
op
Kan extension LanF act(U ) : F act(K(M(E, I)))op → Ab [16].
Theorem 3.9 Given functor F : F act(K(X))op → Ab, there exist isomorphisms
Hn (F act(K(X))op , F ) ∼
= Hn (F act(M(E, I))op , LanF act(U ) F )
op

for all n > 0.

19

 4

Conclusion

The author believes that the results will help in investigation the Goubault
homology of asynchronous systems as the homology groups Hn (K(S), Zε ),
ε ∈ {0, 1}, with coefficients in some suitable systems of Abelian groups.
You can explore the n-deadlocks for asynchronous systems. It is possible
to find homological signs for the existence of bisimilar equivalence between
asynchronous systems, Petri nets, and trace languages.
